snippet: “Souvenir,” an hourlong one-man show, pays homage to “Remembrance of Things Past,” 100 years later.
abstract: “Souvenir,” an hourlong one-man show, pays homage to “Remembrance of Things Past,” 100 years later.
lead_paragraph: Bush Moukarzel’s first line in the one-man play “Souvenir,” now playing at the Abrons Arts Center in New York, is, “For a long time, I went to bed early.” It’s also the very famous first line of Marcel Proust’s “Remembrance of Things Past,” published a century ago this year. Moukarzel’s hourlong piece, which was a sold-out hit in Dublin and London for the theater company Dead Centre, aims not so much to relive Proust’s epic, seven-volume story of social climbing, desire and memory as to distill its yearning, nostalgic essence into fragments of narrative and images. When the show begins, Moukarzel is running on a treadmill, his back to us, instantly conjuring images of being borne back ceaselessly into the past (or, stuck in the present). A giant diptych of Proust hangs overhead. Everywhere, there’s a clutter of half-opened packing boxes, marked cheekily with labels like “Mum,” “Apologies, “Bacon,” “Broken Glass” and (inevitably) “Madeleines.”

headline.main: After Hours | An Irishman’s Inner Marcel Proust
